DOC.HEAD: Female Soldier Blames Policy for Panama Exclusion
With AM-Women-Combat
DOC.TEXT: A female Army intelligence officer whose specialty is Panama filed a complaint over her exclusion from the U.S. invasion there, but said Sunday her problem stems from ``confused'' policy rather than sexism. ``I think that it was not deliberate,'' Sgt. Rhonda Maskus said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' in an interview from the Army's Fort Bragg. Ma. Maskus filed the complaint Jan. 3 with the Army's Office of Inspector General in Washington. Army officials have declined to comment on the complaint. Ms. Maskus, a Spanish linguist and intelligence analyst who is an expert on Panama, described herself as ``a major factor in the contingency planning for Panama.'' But Ms. Maskus, who belongs to the 82nd Airborne Division, did not go to that Latin American country when U.S. forces invaded Dec. 20. Instead, a male soldier she said was not an expert on Panama was sent to a secure U.S. base, Ms. Maskus said. ``Now if I had been a male soldier, without doubt, without question, without hesitation, I would have been the one deployed to Panama,'' she said. Also appearing on ``Face the Nation'' were Christopher Jehn, assistant secretary of defense for personnel; Brian Mitchell, author of ``The Weak Link,'' a book against women in the military; and Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., who supports women serving in combat positions. ``It has been my contention all along that it is because of a confused policy that the Army, especially 82nd Airborne Division, is just not quite sure where to put its females in when comes to actual operational roles, especially considering the mission the 82nd has as a quick deployment force,'' Ms. Maskus said. Jehn acknowledged the Army policy that bans women in combat units but allows them in groups such as supply battalions and military police who can be fired upon may seem inconsistent. ``It seems inconsistent to many, I know,'' he said. ``It is very difficult to defend putting women at risk in one situation and not in others except on the basis of some of the arguments we've heard earlier that the presence of wommen in combat units would in some way or another adversely affect the effectiveness of those units.'' Ms. Maskus said she does not look forward to facing fire but hopes her complaint paves the way for other women who want to serve in the armed forces. ``I'll take it as far I have to take it, which can be all the way up to the Department of the Army, Congress, the president if need be, just to be sure that females that come into the 82nd Airborne Division behind me do not face the same problem,'' she said. The invasion resulted in the surrender of ousted Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was brought to the United States to face drug charges. Twenty-three U.S. servicemen died in the invasion. About 600 of the 24,500 U.S. soldiers who participated in the invasion were women.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Ambassador Held By U.S. Soldiers In Panama
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Cuban ambassador detained for more than two hours. Pick up 7th pvs, `The Cuban....'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. soldiers briefly detained the Cuban ambassador Sunday, officials said. It was the second time he was stopped and searched since the invasion to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Also Sunday, Manuel Solis Palma, a former president under Noriega, was reportedly in the Venezuelan Embassy waiting for word on his petition for asylum. At a roadblock outside the Cuban Embassy, U.S. troops stopped Ambassador Lazaro Mora Secada and two other embassy officials, the Cuban consul said. ``The ambassador was going home in a vehicle with diplomatic plates,'' said the consul, Jose Luis Mendez. ``They took his passport and would not let him leave if he didn't let them check (the group).'' Mendez said he was detained at 1:45 p.m. A U.S. Embassy official confirmed the report, and added that the ambassador had been released by 4 p.m. ``It's been resolved,'' said the official, who was reached by telephone. He did not elaborate. On Dec. 28, Mora was stopped by U.S. forces and had to go with them to obtain documents for another embassy employee traveling with him. The Cuban Embassy has given refuge to Noriega's family. The Panamanian government of Guillermo Endara, which replaced Noriega after the Dec. 20 invasion, has refused to allow the Noriega family to leave for exile in the Dominican Republic. Noriega sought refuge in the Vatican Embassy on Christmas Eve and surrendered to U.S. forces 10 days later. He awaits trial on drug charges in Miami. About 500 Cubans in Panama staged a rally Sunday to publicize their efforts to seek asylum in the United States. Hector Higueras, vice president of the Cuban Refugees Commission of Panama, said the refugees are asking the U.S. and Panamanian governments ``that they give their technical and material support ... for the United States to urgently accept their immigration.'' Higueras said the Cuban refugees do not have permission to work and have no rights in Panama. He said that under a deal between Cuba and the deposed Noriega government, the Cubans paid $8,000 to $20,000 to come to Panama as a transit point to the United States. Solis Palma's wife said Saturday that she believed her husband had taken refuge in the Venezuelan Embassy. Solis Palma was appointed president on Feb. 26 when Arturo Delvalle was removed for trying to fire Noriega. He held the post until Sept. 1, 1989. In Caracas, President Carlos Andres Perez said that his government was studying Solis Palma's petition for asylum. ``This is possible, because we are devoted to the right of asylum and we cannot deny asylum to anyone without an evaluation,'' Perez told reporters. Troops continue to surround several foreign embassies, including those of Cuba and Nicaragua, where an undetermined number of Noriega's officers and cronies are believed to have sought asylum. Noriega's wife, Felicidad, and the couple's three daughters have been inside the Cuban Embassy residence since the night of the invasion and U.S. soldiers have blocked off most traffic in that neighborhood, located in the plush San Francisco district of the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Heads North of Island Territory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with typhoon headed north of Saipan, storm's position, storm believed to have reached peak, water service partly restored on Guam, residents leaving Guam shelters; picks up 10th graf, `The Guam ...' Monday is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Koryn headed north of this U.S. island commonwealth in the Pacific Ocean on Monday with winds gusting to 110 mph, and forecasters believed the storm had hit its peak, officials said. On Guam, crews worked to clear damage and restore water and power service cut when the storm hit Sunday night. By noon Monday (9 p.m. Sunday EST), Koryn's center was 40 miles north of Saipan, and the storm was moving north-northeast at 8 mph, said Navy Lt. Diane Crittenden of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on Guam. The typhoon, with maximum sustained winds of 85 mph and gusts reaching 110 mph, was believed to have reached its peak, she said. If the storm kept to its course, it would not hit any other islands in the Northern Marianas, but might hit the Japanese island of Minami-Tori, according to Ms. Crittendon. Residents on Saipan boarded up houses, put boats to sea and moved to community shelters, said Civil Defense coordinator Felix Sasamopo. The airport was closed. On Guam, water service was restored to about 40 percent of the island's population of 130,000, and 40 percent remained without electricity, said Ben Reyes, a staff officer with Guam Civil Defense. Winds tore tin roofs off two houses in Guam and forced more than 500 people into emergency shelters Sunday, but only a few remained in shelters after the storm passed, said Reyes. Two minor injuries were reported. The Guam airport was reopened after the typhoon passed. Guam is also home to Andersen Air Force Base. Both Guam and the Northern Marianas are located west of the International Date Line.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Cranston Out Of Favor With San Francisco Voters
DOC.TEXT: San Franciscans, who have strongly supported U.S. Sen. Alan Cranston, said by more than a 2-1 margin that he should not seek re-election and they would not vote for him, according to a newspaper poll. City residents surveyed in the poll published in Sunday's editions of the San Francisco Examiner said by a 4-1 margin that Cranston'sconduct on behalf of a troubled savings and loan was improper. But four out of five said the state's senior senator, who has promised to run for a fifth term in 1992, should be allowed to serve out his term. ``If you see these numbers in San Francisco, you can only assume the numbers are worse elsewhere,'' said Bruce Cain, a political scientist who is associate director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California, Berkeley. In the poll conducted from Dec. 26 to Dec. 30 by Richard Hertz Consulting of Bodega Bay, 401 city residents were interviewed by telephone. Cranston, the Democratic majority whip, is one of five senators under fire for interceding with regulators on behalf of Charles Keating Jr., president of Lincoln Savings & Loan. Cranston's re-election committee and voter registration efforts received a total of more than $1.2 million in contributions from Keating. The institution went bankrupt, and regulators estimate taxpayers will have to pay up to $2 billion to cover its loss of federally insured deposits through sham land transactions, fraud and racketeering. Cranston called his backing of Keating a ``political mistake,'' but denied it was improper or illegal. Asked whether Cranston acted properly, 53.1 percent of respondents said no, 10 percent said yes, and 36.9 percent said they did not know. To the question of whether the senator should run again, 56.4 percent said no, 27.7 percent said yes and 16 percent said they did not know. Asked whether they would vote for Cranston again, 53.4 percent said no, 23.4 percent said yes and 23.2 percent said they did not know. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percent. When Cranston first took office in 1968, San Franciscans gave him 80 percent of their vote. He received 78 percent in 1974, 80 percent in 1980 and 74 percent in 1986, his closest election in which he won by less than 1 percent statewide.

DOC.HEAD: Ambulance From Mother Teresa's Hospital Kills 2 When Brakes Fail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with details, quote. Pickup 6th graf `Mother Teresa won...'
DOC.TEXT: An ambulance operated by Mother Teresa's hospital veered onto a sidewalk when its brakes failed, killing two pedestrians and seriously injuring two others, police said Sunday. Police initially reported the 79-year-old Nobel Peace Prize winner was in the ambulance when the accident happened Saturday. But police and Mother Teresa's fellow Roman Catholic nuns said Sunday she was not in the vehicle. ``There was confusion because she reached the scene within minutes,'' a police duty officer said Sunday, speaking on condition of anonymity. The accident occurred near the Missionaries of Charity building where Mother Teresa resides. Several nuns, wearing blue and white saris identical to Mother Teresa's attire, were in the ambulance, adding to the confusion. The ambulance was carrying medical supplies but no patients when the accident happened. The ambulance struck two pedestrians who had just stepped off the sidewalk into the street, police said. The vehicle, running out of control after its brakes failed, then veered onto the sidewalk and struck two more people, according to the police reports. Mother Teresa accompanied the four seriously injured people to a nearby hospital, where two of them later died, the police report said. Mother Teresa won the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize for her work among the poor. She suffered a heart attack Sept. 5 but resumed work last week. The Yugoslav-born nun founded the Missionaries of Charity in October 1959 in an abandoned hostel donated by the city of Calcutta. The order, which was formally recognized by the Vatican in 1965, expanded and now has 3,000 nuns working in 87 countries.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Siamese Twins Separated In Australia, Doing Well
DOC.TEXT: Siamese twin girls were reported in stable condition Sunday after being separated in a 7{-hour operation at Royal Children's Hospital. Hospital spokesman Don Kinsey said the girls were progressing well after the operation to separate them on Thursday. Kinsey said a 25-member surgical team led by Dr. Keith Stokes separated the girls, who were 11 days old on the day of the operation. The operation involved separating two livers and two digestive tracts. Kinsey said the operation was the fourth successful separation of Siamese twins carried out at the hospital and the 33rd successful operation of its kind since 1690 when international records for the operation were first kept. The name of the family was not revealed.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Tropical Storm Off Guam Upgraded To Typhoon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with storm upgraded to typhoon, details. Pickup 7th graf `All Navy...'
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Koryn became a full-fledged typhoon Sunday, lashing this U.S. Pacific territory with strong winds and heavy rains, toppling trees and flooding low-lying areas, authorities said. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage to structures. As of 5 p.m. (2 a.m. EST), Koryn had sustained winds of 75 mph, with gusts to 90 mph, according to Navy Lt. Joe Atangan of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center Rapid Response Team. The storm's center was located 45 miles east of the northern tip of the island, where Andersen Air Force Base is located, Atangan said. The typhoon was ``quasi stationary'' but was expected to move off to the north-northwest, skirting the northern coast, he said. Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands remained under a typhoon alert, although the projected path of the storm would take it south of the Marianas and away from any other islands, Atangan said. There were reports on Guam of intermittent power outages because of downed lines, and flooding was reported in many areas, the Pacific Daily News said. ``There's lots of coconuts on the roads,'' Atangan said. All Navy aircraft were placed in hangers for protection against the strong winds, and the USS Haleakala was sent out to sea to weather the storm, said Lt. Dave Lee. Three other warships were allowed to remain in port, he said. The 12 planes at Andersen, including 11 B-52s, were parked behind fortifications as the storm approached, said base spokesman Capt. Wayne Perry. A tropical storm has sustained winds ranging from 39 to 73 mph. A typhoon has a minimum sustained surface wind of 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Carrying Radioactive Material Crashes, Killing 1, Forcing Evacuation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `They were...,' to CORRECT spelling of material to Americium, sted Amercurian. Dayne in 9th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A car crashed into a tractor-trailer carrying low-level radioactive material on Interstate 85, killing one person and prompting the evacuation of about 225 people, officials said. Lynne Denise Beatty, 29, of Charlotte was killed in the accident at 9:05 p.m. Friday, the state highway patrol said. Ms. Beatty suffered a seizure while driving south on I-85 and her car crossed the median and struck the tractor-trailer head on, police said. The truck, owned by Consolidated Freightways, continued about three-tenths of a mile before it stopped and the cab burst into flames, according to the report filed by Highway Patrol Trooper W.D. Greene. James Nelson Brown of Charlotte, the driver, was treated for minor injuries. As a precaution against radioactive contamination, authorities evacuated 75 homes in a quarter-mile area around the accident scene at the exit ramp of U.S. 29 onto I-85, said Frank Thomason, communications supervisor with the Rowan County Emergency Operations Center. About 225 residents left their homes; 52 went to a shelter set up by the county, authorities said. They were allowed to return home about 2 a.m. Saturday after emergency personnel learned that the radioactive material consisted of Cesium 137 and Americium 241, both used for soil testing, authorities said. The cargo was bound for Durham. ``It has a very low radioactivity,'' Greene said. The radioactive material did not pose a significant threat to people in the area, said Dayne Brown, director of the N.C. Division of Radiation Protection. A hazardous materials team went to the scene and inspected for any radioactive leaks, Thomason said. ``If there was any leak it was very minimal,'' he said. Southbound lanes of the interstate were reopened at about 3 a.m., and northbound lanes were reopened about 6 a.m.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
At Least 43 Killed in Disco Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with report that 44 bodies recovered, CORRECTS governor's middle name to Perez, short circuit suspected as cause
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in a basement discotheque early Sunday, and at least 43 people died of smoke inhalation, said officials in this northern city. Firefighters extinguished the blaze which erupted about 3:45 a.m. (9:45 p.m. EST Saturday) in the Flying disco. About 130 people were inside when the fire broke out, said Civil Gov. Carlos Perez Anadon. Forty-three people died and three others were hospitalized for smoke inhalation, said the civil governor in this city about 160 miles northeast of the capital Madrid. EFE, the official Spanish news agency, said 44 bodies were recovered. The civil governor was quoted by EFE as saying the dead ranged in age from 35 to 50 years old. The news agency quoted an unidentified government spokesman as saying an electrical short circuit was suspected of sparking the blaze after first causing a power blackout. Six years ago, more than 90 people died in a basement disco fire in the Alcala 20 discotheque in Madrid, also from inhalation of toxic fumes and smoke.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Hits Remote Northwest
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake cracked buildings in northwest China's Qinghai province Sunday, but there were no reports of casualties, the official Xinhua News Agency said. It said the quake measuring 6.7 on the Richter scale hit Mangnai, a small outpost 1,300 miles west of the capital Beijing. People at a nearby oilfield felt the temblor and found cracks in their buildings. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake meauring 6 can cause severe damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Sweeps by Guam, Heads for Marianas
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Koryn, packing sustained winds of 75 mph and gusts to 90 mph, swept past this U.S. Pacific territory Sunday night before heading toward the Northern Mariana Islands, authorities said. High winds and heavy rains knocked out electricity over 30 percent of Guam, cutting power to 56 of the island's 90 water wells, officials said. Winds ranging from 35 to 55 mph ripped tin roofs off two houses and forced 21 people into emergcy shelters, the officials said. There were two reports of minor injuries. A 50-year-old man suffered a cut ear while trying to put up shutters and a 46-year-old woman was injured when she was blown into a pole. Both were treated and released from Guam Memorial Hospital, a hospital spokesman said. As of 7 p.m. (4 a.m. EST), Koryn was 44 miles northeast of Guam, moving to the northwest at 8 mph, according to Navy Lt.j.g. Ken Minogue of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center Rapid Response Team. The typhoon was forecast to pass to the north of Rota, the most southern of the Northern Marianas, a U.S. commonwealth, some 40 miles north of Guam, Minogue said. Rota was getting heavy rains and winds up to 50 mph, the same conditions the Mariana islands of Tinian and Saipan could expect Monday, he said. On Guam, all Navy aircraft were placed in hangers for protection against the strong winds, and the USS Haleakala was sent out to sea to weather the storm, said Lt. Dave Lee. Three other warships were allowed to remain in port, he said. Twelve planes, including 11 B-52s, at Andersen Air Force Base on the north coast of Guam, were parked behind fortifications as the storm approached, said base spokesman Capt. Wayne Perry. A tropical storm has sustained winds ranging from 39 to 73 mph. A typhoon has a minimum sustained surface wind of 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Disco Blaze Kills 43, Electrical Malfunction Blamed
DOC.TEXT: An electrical fire broke out in a discotheque early Sunday, giving off poisonous smoke that killed 43 people and injured three others, said officials in this northern city. The victims were in the basement of the club where a local band was playing when the fire broke out, and many of the dead ``were still sitting in their chairs'' when they were found, said Deputy Mayor Luis Garcia Nieto. The blaze began shortly before 2:40 a.m. near the front door of the Flying discotheque, filled with about 130 people, government spokesman Ignacio Bruna said in this city about 160 miles northeast of the capital Madrid. The smoke funneled through air conditioning ducts down to the basement, where the dance floor, bar and lounge are located, said the central government representative in Zaragoza, Carlos Perez Anadon. Firefighters arrived eight minutes after the blaze broke out and quickly extinguished the flames, but rescue workers could do little to save the victims, said Garcia Nieto, speaking to Spanish National Radio (RNE). The speed with which people died may have been due to the presence of hydrocyanic acid in the smoke, the national news service EFE quoted civil protection head Antonio Herrera as saying. Hydrocyanic acid is used to produce acryclics. Bruna said a woman was being treated for smoke inhalation in the intensive care unit of Miguel Servet hospital, which reported her condition as serious. Two others had been treated for minor injuries, he added. He said preliminary information indicated the fire was caused by an electrical overload. ``It began on the ground floor, near the door,'' he said, adding all 43 killed had been in the discotheque's basement and died of smoke inhalation. At the municipal morgue, several dozen anxious people waited to find out whether family members were among the dead. Bruna said 25 victims had been identified as area residents. Their ages ranged from 21 to 52, but most were between 25 and 35 years old. Garcia Nieto said the discotheque had been licensed Oct. 3, 1984, a year after authorities passed a new series of tough fire regulations after a Dec. 17, 1983 fire killed more than 90 people in the Alcala 20 discotheque in Madrid. He said the discotheque had been routinely investigated since then to ensure it complied with the regulations. ``It would appear (the discotheque) was in compliance with all the regulations,'' Bruna said. The national news agency EFE quoted a waitress who said the fire blocked one of the two stairways leading from the basement to the street. ``I smelled something burning, and in seconds nobody could get out,'' said the waitress, who added she escaped up the main stairway after seeing the emergency steps were blocked by flames. ``While I was going up towards the main door, a group of customers, probably blinded by the smoke, were trying to get up the emergency steps. But I'm sure they couldn't get out, because the fire was there,'' said the waitress, who was not identified.

Calls to drive Armenians from the capital of Soviet Azerbaijan touched off a riot in which 22 people were killed, mostly Armenians, Soviet radio reported Sunday. The Saturday night rampage in the southern republic was only the latest violence between Armenians and Azerbaijanis, who have been locked in a nearly two-year feud over who should govern Nagorno-Karabakh, a mostly Armenian enclave. Radio Moscow said news that an Azerbaijani had been killed and another wounded by an axe-wielding Armenian family in Baku, Azerbaijan's capital, was announced at a Saturday night rally in the city's central square attended by 150,000 people. The two Azerbaijanis earlier Saturday had demanded that the Armenian family leave Baku and a struggle ensued, the radio said. The riot broke out after ``calls were made at the rally to drive the Armenians out of the city,'' the radio correspondent reported from the Caspian Sea port city. Twenty-two people were killed and 26 wounded, the radio reported. It quoted local Interior Ministry officials as saying most of the casualties were Armenians. Nagorno-Karabakh, an enclave of 160,000 people, has been under control of mainly Shiite Moslem Azerbaijan since 1923. Attempts to annex it to predominantly Christian Armenia spurred unrest that has left about 200 people dead over the last two years. Azerbaijan last week renewed a railroad blockade of Armenia, which gets most of its supplies through the neighboring republic.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Pass Halfway Point of Long Space Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with flight director's comments on first half of flight, broken experiment being fixed; picks up 14th graf, `The astronauts...'
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's astronauts were busy with medical and science experiments Sunday as they soared past the halfway point of what a flight director called a ``flawless flight.'' Near the midpoint, the crew was beaming to Earth a television shot of mission specialist Marsha Ivins checking David Low with an echocardiograph, a device which generates a two-dimensional, cross-section image of the heart. It is one of many experiments the astronauts are conducting to determine how well the human body adapts to weightlessness in space. Columbia, launched Tuesday, is scheduled to land at 2:59 a.m. PST Friday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Assessing the first half of the trip, flight director Al Pennington said ``it has been a flawless flight. We have a beautifully running orbiter. ``We have achieved our main objectives of releasing the Syncom satellite and retrieving the Long Duration Exposure Facility,'' he said. ``For the rest of the time we will do the secondary experiments and work on the EDO objectives.'' EDO means extended duration orbiter. The 10-day flight is the second longest shuttle mission yet and is intended as a stepping stone toward even longer shuttle flights and months-long trips aboard space station Freedom. The sixth day of the 10-day mission began when fellow Notre Dame alumni serenaded Columbia pilot Jim Wetherbee with a rousing wakeup song. The strains of ``Notre Dame Victory March,'' sung by an ad hoc Mission Control choir, were beamed to the shuttle at 12:30 a.m. ``That was provided by local alumni of a school you know pretty well,'' said Mission Control's Ken Bowersox. ``Yeah, there's a lot of Damers down there,'' said Wetherbee, a 1974 graduate of the school in aerospace engineering. Commander Dan Brandenstein, Wetherbee and mission specialists Bonnie Dunbar, Ivins and Low were continuing experiments begun the day of launch, including IMAX movie camera observations of selected locations on earth. ``This is the second-longest shuttle mission that we've had so far, so we can do some good materials science experiments up here and we can also get some very good medical data,'' Low said Saturday. One experiment, involving melting and resolidifying a metal, broke down Friday when a crack developed in a glass container, probably because of overheating. But Pennington said Sunday that experts on the ground had worked out a solution to the problem and the astronauts were working to resume operation of the experiment. The glass container, called an ampul, contains the element indium, a metal that melts at a relatively low temperature. It had been feared that the cracked glass could shatter, sending shards of glass floating around the cabin. Pennington said one of the astronauts, wearing a mask and gloves, removed the cracked container and carefully vacuumed the machine. There was no sign of any loose glass shards, Pennington said. A new glass ampul will be installed later Sunday, he said. The astronauts on Friday captured the 11-ton Long Duration Exposure Facility, a space laboratory, and tucked it into the shuttle's cargo bay in time to save it and 57 experiments on board from burning up in an expected March 9 plunge into Earth's atmosphere. The astronauts took time out for a little fun Saturday afternoon, playing the song ``Attack of the Killer Tomatoes'' from a movie by the same name as they showed Mission Control a drawing of LDEF wildly entwined in tomato vines. It was a joking reference to an LDEF experiment that consists of 12.5 million tomato seeds for student experiments and research. Brandenstein's 22-year-old daughter, Adelle, had sent a greeting to the crew asking, ``Have the killer tomatoes attacked yet?'' ``I guess that answers Adelle's question earlier,'' the commander said.

DOC.HEAD: Nine More Boat People Bodies Found
DOC.TEXT: Nine more decomposed bodies of Vietnamese boat people were found off the coast of Malaysia on Sunday, bringing the total found in the past two days to 23, police said. They were believed to have drowned after their boat sank in rough waters off the Trengganu coast, the National News Agency Bernama reported from Kuala Trengganu, the capital of Trengganu state. It quoted police and hospital sources. Fourteen bodies were found Saturday along the coast, 180 miles northeast of Kuala Lumpur. The bodies have been buried at the Vietnamese refugee cemetery in Kuala Trengganu. Early last month, 15 bodies believed to be those of Vietnamese boat people were spotted along the Marang coast. Waters in the South China Sea off Trengganu are rough this time of year because it is the monsoon season. Malaysia accepts Vietnamese boat people for temporary asylum pending permanent settlement in the United States, Australia, Canada and other countries.

DOC.HEAD: Police Fire Tear Gas to Break Up Anti-Government Protests in Downtown Seoul
DOC.TEXT: Riot police fired tear gas and punched protesters Sunday to break up hundreds of radical students who surged through the streets of a fashionable downtown shopping area yelling anti-government slogans. More than 100 students were arrested in the two-hour clash and there were some injuries, but a number was not immediately available. Police hit some protesters with their fists and shields, and students fought back, kicking and screaming. The clashes broke out after 700 radicals were blocked from holding a commemorative rally for a student tortured to death by police three years ago. ``Drive out yankees!'' students yelled, ``Overthrow (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' At one point students attacked about 40 riot police surrounding about 20 other students, who had been detained and forced to kneel on the street. ``Pig!'' one student yelled, grabbing a policeman's helmet. Riot police fired tear gas grenades into the narrow streets, where hundreds of citizens were browsing in boutiques. Stores closed and shoppers fled, coughing and choking on the gas. One plainclothes policeman who chased a protester into a fried chicken restaurant was chased out by screaming customers who tried to grab the policeman by his coat. ``Chun Doo-hwan must be punished and his successor Roh Tae-woo must resign to pave the way for democracy!'' students shouted. They also demanded the withdrawal of 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense pact. Radical students, a small but vocal minority on campuses, have called for the punishment of Roh and his predecessor, Chun Doo-hwan. They hold both men responsible for a government crackdown on a civil uprising in Kwangju in 1980 that left at least 200 people dead and 1,500 wounded. Violent radical student protests were staged Saturday in Kwangju, a provincial city south of the capital. Sunday's rally in Seoul was in honor of Park Chong-chol, a university student whose death by torture in 1987 touched off nationwide protests. Police banned the rally in advance.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Elects First Woman Leader
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party of Great Britain on Sunday elected its first woman general secretary, Nina Temple, who is the party's news media and publicity officer. The party's executive committee voted 34 to 1, with three abstaining. Miss Temple, 33, succeeds Gordon McLennan, 62, who retired as leader of the 7,500-member party after 14 years. She said the party ``has become completely marginalized in British society _partly because of its association with those huge edifices in Eastern Europe which were so undemocratic, and partly because of our own self-imposed limitations.'' Miss Temple joined the Communist Party at age 13 and became general secretary of the Young Communist League. Her father, Landon Temple, runs Progressive Tours, which promotes visits to the Soviet Union. Hard-liners broke away from the Communist Party of Great Britain in 1984, following McLennan's attempts at moderation, and formed a splinter party.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Activists Call for More Democracy
With AM-China-Flight, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 100 activists marched to the governor's residence on Sunday to plea for more democracy before Britain hands this colony back to China in 1997. They presented a petition addressed to British Foreign Minister Douglas Hurd, who is in Hong Kong on a four-day visit. The protesters want to double the number of directly elected legislators to 20 of the governing body's 56 seats next year. Marching from a downtown park to Governor's House _ the official residence and office of Gov. Sir David Wilson _ the demonstrators chanted ``We want democracy, we want human rights'' and ``Full democracy to people of Hong Kong.'' ``We are not asking for sympathy from Britain, we are asking for the rights we deserve,'' said Yeung Sum, a spokesman for the march. ``We hope Hurd would respect Hong Kong people's wishes to set up a democratic political system in 1991.'' The demonstration was organized by the Joint Committee on the Promotion of Democratic Government, which says it includes 150 trade unions, student groups and other organizations. In the letter to Hurd, the committee said Hong Kong is a political orphan because ``China suppresses pro-democracy movements in Hong Kong and Britain betrays Hong Kong people's rights.'' ``We who cannot emigrate have to face this problem ... and set up a real democratic political system,'' the letter said. Under a 1984 agreement, Hong Kong is to retain its free-wheeling capitalist system and a high degree of autonomy for 50 years after 1997. But since the June 4 crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in China, confidence in Beijing's promise has evaporated. Since June 4, the government has been pushing a plan to speed up the pace and extent of democratization in the colony. The government currently is calling for 18 of the 56 legislature's seats to be contested in 1991, about 50 percent in 1997 and 100 percent in 2003. Currently 24 of the 56 members in the Legislative Council are elected by bodies representing labor, business and districts. Aside from the 10 popularly elected, the rest are appointed by the government. When he arrived in Hong Kong on Saturday, Hurd said the ground rules would be ready for the direct elections in ``a few weeks.'' Last month, the Chinese-appointed committee writing the Basic Law, the blueprint to run the territory after 1997, decided that fewer than 18 seats would be directly elected in the legislature after 1997.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette, Alcohol Ads Appear in Children's Video Games
DOC.TEXT: Signs advertising cigarette and alcohol are appearing in children's video arcade games, with video motorcycles racing past Budweiser billboards and race cars speeding underneath Marlboro banners. One game, Super Monaco GP, manufactured by Sega of America, includes Marlboro race cars, billboards, banners and Marlboro signs in the crowd. Occasionally the cars race past a building in which all of the windows have been replaced by Marlboro logos. In Sega's arcade game Power Drift, race cars pass Budweiser billboards. Philip Morris, the maker of Marlboro, and Anheuser Busch, which makes Budweiser, said Friday that they had not authorized the use of their brand names or logos. Philip Morris said it had asked Sega to recall the games. Sega said in a statement that the inclusion of the logos was ``simply a game designer's innocent attempt to mimic real-life locations.'' It said it was in the process of removing them. The statement did not indicate how many games were manufactured or how long they have been in use. ``Super Monaco GP is essentially one big Marlboro ad,'' says Dr. John W. Richards of the Medical College of Georgia, who has investigated the video game cigarette ads. ``A child playing Super Monaco GP is exposed to literally hundreds of Marlboro ads during the game, if he's good,'' Richards wrote last month in a letter of complaint to the Federal Trade Commission. Richards is president of Doctors Ought to Care, or DOC, an anti-smoking group. ``If he's not good and doesn't reach `extended play,' then he'll see only 50 or so Marlboro ads,'' Richards wrote. A copy of the letter was obtained by The Associated Press. ``I think it's regrettable at best, and scandalous at worst, that this is happening,'' said Dr. Ronald M. Davis, director of the Office on Smoking and Health of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control. ``It's a strong indication that the cigarette industry is interested in luring children to begin to smoke. Certainly with all the resources available to the cigarette companies, they'd prevent this obvious copyright infringement if they weren't interested in kids,'' he said. Smoking kills 390,000 Americans each year, and 90 percent of smokers take up the habit as teen-agers, Davis said. Steven Weiss, manager of media relations for Philip Morris USA in New York, said the company only recently found out about the video game advertisements. ``Sega has not asked permission to use our logo, and, moreover, we would not grant such permission to use any of our cigarette logos in any video game, especially those played by minors,'' Weiss said in an interview Friday. ``All our cigarette advertising and promotions are directed at informed adult smokers only,'' he said. Weiss said Philip Morris wrote to Sega on Nov. 20 asking the company to stop using the Marlboro logo and recall all games that include it. The letter was sent seven days after Rep. Thomas Luken of Ohio wrote Philip Morris to say his subcommittee wanted to hold hearings on the video game advertisements. A video game in Australia called Pole Position contained the Marlboro logo in 1983, according to the March 5, 1983, issue of the Medical Journal of Australia. The journal said that a Philip Morris official in Australia had been informed then of the existence of the logos in the games. Scott Murdock, director of sales promotion and merchandising for Anheuser Busch Inc., which makes Budweiser, said in a statement that the company had not authorized the use of its brand name or logo. ``Based on the information you have provided to us, we will ask our legal department to investigate the matter,'' he said. Dave Rosen, co-chairman of the board of Sega of America, said in a statement that ``there is absolutely no form of paid or intentional advertising displayed in any of Sega's arcade or consumer video games.'' ``We're already in the process of removing any graphics that could unintentionally be construed as real-life product in our games and packaging,'' he said. Richards said he has seen the games at video arcades in South Carolina, Tennessee and Georgia. The Associated Press found the same games at a video arcade in New York City's Times Square. The Federal Trade Commission, which regulates advertising, said it cannot disclose whether it is investigating the video game advertisements. But the commission's new chairman, Janet D. Steiger said at the time of her confirmation last summer that she is concerned about the issue. ``Allegations that tobacco and alcohol products are being marketed to young people are matters of serious concern that deserve priority attention,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Campaign Rumors Seen Straining Friendship With Barry
DOC.TEXT: They marched together in the civil rights army around Martin Luther King Jr. They call themselves friends. But whatever remains of the relationship between Marion Barry and Jesse Jackson is severely strained by today's political realities. Barry is fighting for political survival as mayor of the nation's capital and sees his old friend Jackson as a formidable obstacle. Observers of the byzantine local political scene in Washington speculate that whatever the mayor did or didn't say in a recent interview with the Los Angeles Times stemmed from his unease over the fact Jackson established residence in the capital in time to qualify for a campaign for mayor. ``Jesse don't want to run nothing but his mouth,'' Barry was quoted as telling a Times reporter. The mayor spent much of the past week trying to extinguish the political fires that his comments sparked. Jackson has said he believes Barry's assertions that he never made any of the comments attributed to him in the Times profile. But Jackson aides and top city officials said Jackson was angry enough to call the newspaper and ask whether Barry really made the remarks. He was told that the interview was tape-recorded. It is easy to understand why Barry may frequently be thinking about his former civil rights colleague. Barry and Jackson, who have been friends since both worked with King, have seen their relationship put under the microscope since Jackson's April relocation to the nation's capital fueled rumors that he would try to unseat Barry. Jackson has said repeatedly he would never run against Barry, but he left open the possibility he would enter the race if Barry decided against seeking a fourth term. ``Given that Jackson has not eliminated the possibility of running, his presence has cast a heavy shadow over Barry's reelection effort,'' says Julius Hobson, a former city official who is now an advisor to Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va. ``He is not an announced candidate, but he is doing all the things that a candidate has always done in this town _ like visiting the ministers _ and that certainly makes it more difficult for Barry.'' Barry, despite trailing several rivals in fund-raising, is nonetheless predicting he can coast to reelection. But federal prosecutors continue their investigation of Barry's ties to a convicted drug dealer, and an indictment of the mayor would cripple him politically and open the door for a Jackson candidacy, the thinking goes. Top city officials say Jackson has indicated to them he may be interested in representing the city as a ``shadow'' senator on Capitol Hill. The non-voting position, which would pay almost $80,000 per year, is designed to serve as a platform from which to lobby for statehood. Ironically, the latest tensions between the two old friends flared despite statements over several weeks from Jackson associates that indicated he was growing less interested in running for mayor. Jackson recently adopted statehood as his new crusade _ calling it ``the major social justice issue of the day'' _ and is scheduled to announce a national statehood lobbying effort on Monday. In conversations with congressional leaders, Jackson also has been told that having Barry at the helm of the city makes statehood a much tougher proposition, according to Jackson aides. ``Jesse has reminded them that Maryland wasn't disenfranchised when Governor (Marvin) Mandel went to jail,'' said one Jackson aide who spoke only on condition of anonymity. ``But the problems with Marion on the Hill are obvious to Jesse, and he can't avoid thinking about them or dealing with them.'' ``Statehood works for Jesse,'' Hobson says, ``if that's what he really wants to do.'' And for now, the rest of Washington _ from Barry on down _ can only wonder about Jackson's real intentions.

DOC.HEAD: Hitchhiking Becomes Commuting Mode in Washington Suburb
DOC.TEXT: A group of well-dressed hitchhikers was there waiting when Rose McMurray pulled into the Rolling Valley Mall parking lot in search of the ``warm bodies'' that would enable her to use the express lanes on the interstate and get to work on time. ``It's a win-win situation for everybody,'' McMurray says as she piles two riders into her car. Drivers get to use the high-occupancy vehicle, or HOV, lanes, and cut 20 minutes or more off from their commute through mind-numbing traffic to downtown Washington, D.C. Passengers get a free trip. Without government direction or subsidy, the informal, instant carpooling system has evolved into a unique commuting mode that relieves pressure on the subsidized bus system, cuts congestion and saves commuters money. Transportation researchers call it the ``Springfield underground'' because it started with the opening 15 years ago of HOV lanes down the center of I-395 to the Washington suburb of Springfield, Va. The two-lane HOV lanes are restricted to buses and cars carrying three or more passengers during rush hour. Most carpooling involves people from the same office or the same neighborhood or those matched by formal programs. But in Springfield and the nearby bedroom community of Burke, it's stand there and take your chances. The only other area where the instant carpooling occurs on a large scale is at bus stops leading to the east entrance to the Bay Bridge between Oakland and San Francisco, according to a study by the Urban Institute. Arlee Reno, who heads transportation projects for the Urban Institute, said he has taken a slide show on Springfield's hitchhiking commuting system to Houston, Minneapolis, Seattle and Los Angeles. But researchers caution that several conditions have to be met if such systems are to work. Among them: _At least 500 commuters in the given area. _HOV lanes that save enough time to give drivers a reason to pick up passengers. _A parallel bus system that gives hitchhiking commuters an alternative if no cars show up. One drawback of the system is the reluctance of people to climb into a car with a stranger. But riders see little risk with three people in the car. ``A requirement of two persons per vehicle in order to use the HOV lanes would undoubtedly result in a much higher level of psychological resistance to instant carpooling,'' Reno said in a study of the Springfield system. The ``Springfield underground'' has been so successful that nearly all the spaces in park-and-ride lots along the route are taken up by hitchhikers, ranging from stylishly dressed single women to uniformed military officers heading for the Pentagon. At one lot, surveyors watched 553 people get into cars with strangers and only 25 board buses that pass by the lot. Drivers call out their destinations and the next riders in line pile in. Ms. McMurray alternates between driving and hitching rides at the mall, located about 20 miles southwest of downtown Washington. ``All we need is warm bodies for the express lane,'' she says. Dottie Cousineau, head of commuter programs for Fairfax County, said the system has freed morning buses for other areas. Some riders also hitch rides in Washington to get home, but Ms. Cousineau said the system doesn't work as well because workers have to get to limited pickup points, including ones near the Washington Monument and at the Pentagon. Ms. Cousineau said she has never heard of a complaint about the system from a driver or a rider. ``I guess it's because it's entirely voluntary,'' she said. Instant carpooling has fostered a new riding culture and etiquette. The 30-minute rides may feature the unfriendly silences more common in elevators or, on the other hand, convivial commutes that cover the gamut of political and social discussion. On the morning after the U.S. invasion of Panama, a military officer on his way to the Pentagon discussed the timing of the operation. On another day in another car, an Agricultural Department worker criticized farm subsidies. But the most common topics are the weather and the difficulty of getting to work in the nation's capital. For the commuter, a roundtrip between Fairfax County and Washington can cost as much as $6.80 a day _ $2.40 each way on buses and the subway and $2.00 to park at a Metro station. With the ride-sharing program, the trip is free for the passengers. One private lot owned by a movie house was selling parking stickers that included their value in movie tickets. Drivers still have to pay for gas and downtown parking, but they get to work faster. Metropolitan transit officials like the system too, although bus ridership has decreased on the route. ``More power to them,'' said Metro spokeswoman Marilyn Dicus. ``We all have the same goal _ to get more than one person in a vehicle.''

DOC.HEAD: 100-Year-Old Congressional Candidate Says He's Running for Children's Sake
LaserPhoto RA1
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Henry Stenhouse says he started thinking about running for Congress when he saw all the young relatives and friends who turned up for his 100th birthday party last month. ``I got to thinking about the children of this country,'' Stenhouse said Friday as he sat in his small cluttered ophthalmology office. ``I've been concerned about them for a long time. ``We've been doing a lot of bad planning in this country,'' he said. ``And it's not us that's going to catch it, it's the children.'' Last week Stenhouse, who has never held public office, hitched a ride with a visiting son for the 60-mile trip to Raleigh to file as a Republican candidate for the 3rd Congressional District. His life has not been the same since. ``I've never been under such a siege in my life,'' he said, as he answered the third phone call in less than 30 minutes. ``I've had calls from everywhere, people stopping by wanting to help with the campaign. It's been just wonderful.'' Stenhouse said he hasn't worked much on a campaign plan yet, but expects to use a lot of word-of-mouth advertising and speaking to groups whenever he gets the chance. ``I haven't had much experience with public speaking, but I know I've got the capacity,'' he said. ``My father could hold an audience spellbound, so quiet you could hear a pin drop, so I know I've got it in me.'' He acknowledged, however, ``It might be hard for me to speak without making some people mad.'' Stenhouse opposes welfare programs, believes mandatory seat belt laws should be repealed and thinks women who have children should stay home to raise them. ``I'm going to get some opposition on that one, loads of it,'' Stenhouse said. ``But when a woman has children, she has a responsibility to raise them, to care for them, not shuttle them off to some day-care place. You can't have it all and children, too.'' Welfare, he said, is the responsibility of churches, not government. ``I think we've got sidetracked somehow,'' he said. ``The government should have never got into it. I think it's the duty of churches to look after the needy in their community, but they aren't doing it.'' Mandatory seat belt laws, he said, are just an example of big, intrusive government. The three small rooms in Stenhouse's office, where he walks from home three days a week to see some of his old patients, are crowded with files, stacks of correspondence, books and pamphlets. The walls and shelves are covered with photographs and remembrances of a Navy career that took him to China, the Philippines and the Virgin Islands. The office door has a brass nameplate that was his father's, also a doctor. Near it is a color photograph of President and Mrs. Bush, sent to him when he turned 100. ``The first vote I ever cast was for William Howard Taft against Theodore Roosevelt and Woodrow Wilson,'' in 1912, Stenhouse said. ``I've been involved with Republican politics for a long time.'' Stenhouse was born in Colorado on Dec. 7, 1889, when much of the West ``was real frontier country still. Indians _ the works.'' He followed his father into medicine. While interning at a Denver hospital, Stenhouse joined the Navy as a physician. He was in the Philippines when World War I began. The enemy he mainly fought was the influenza epidemic that wiped out thousands of servicemen. When he retired from the Navy in 1937, he wound up in North Carolina, where his recently widowed father-in-law lived. Stenhouse himself was widowed in 1983. He and his wife had five children. Stenhouse said he now spends a lot of time reading, particularly the National Review. ``That Bill Buckley, now that's a smart fellow,'' he said. ``He has had a lot of influence on my thinking. Of course, I keep a dictionary right there with me so I can look up some of the words he uses.'' Stenhouse said he never expected the attention his candidacy has drawn _ interviews, invitations to speak, even a request to appear on ``The Tonight Show'' with Johnny Carson. But he said it has energized him. ``I can't help thinking that a lot of people must think like I do,'' he said. ``There is a lot of latent patriotism and common sense in this country, but it's going to take something to break it open. Maybe this can help do that.'' Thus far, the only other candidate to file for the congressional seat is the incumbent, Martin Lancaster, a Democrat. Stenhouse said if he wins, he promises not to serve more than two terms. That would have him retiring shortly after his 105th birthday.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Ferry Sinks Near Dhaka, 100 Feared Lost
DOC.TEXT: A ferry carrying about 150 people sank Sunday night in a river outside Dhaka, and only about 50 passengers were reported to have swum to shore, police said. Darkness prevented any rescue efforts, and by midnight no bodies had been recovered, police said. The ferry went down in the Dhaleswari River near Mushiganj town, 20 miles southeast of the Bangladesh capital, Dhaka, around 7 p.m. A police official, contacted by telephone and speaking on condition of anonymity, said there were about 150 people aboard the ferry. ``We have reports of 50 people swimming ashore,'' he said. ``We don't yet know what had happened to the others.'' With the winter temperature dropping to 50 degrees during the night, most passengers were in the hull of the ferry, the police said. They said a clear picture about fatalities was unlikely to emerge before Monday morning, when divers would be sent to the scene. The ferry, which police said might have sunk because of overloading, was on a short run from Munshiganj to Dhaka.

DOC.HEAD: Powell Says Military Offers Great Opportunities for Blacks
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said Sunday the armed forces offer black Americans equal opportunity ``more so than any other form of endeavor in our society.'' Powell, the first black to be named the nation's highest-ranking uniformed officer, also said he does not believe the all-volunteer U.S. military has become disproportionately black. ``I don't think it's out of proportion,'' he said, adding that ``anybody who is willing to serve, qualified to serve, proud to serve should be allowed to serve.'' Blacks currently comprise about 21 percent of the armed forces, compared with about 12 percent of the overall U.S. population. Powell was interviewed on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley'' on the eve of the holiday marking the birthday of the late Martin Luther King Jr. He was asked whether he considers the U.S. military a ``meritocracy'' and equal-opportunity employer. Powell replied: ``More so than any other form of endeavor in our society. I've very proud of what we have done in the military over the years, and I think for the most part it is a meritocracy. You are not limited by anything but your own ability.'' In another development, the Washington-based American Council on Education said in a report for release Monday that because of increased selectivity and benefits within the armed forces, the military is becoming more competitive with colleges in recruiting high-ability, college-eligible blacks. It cited a Congressional Budget Office study finding that in 1987, ``Black and white recruits tended to come from different socioeconomic strata within their respective populations, with black recruits coming disproportionately from areas with above-average black incomes and better-educated black adults.'' ``Only 44 percent of black, male, active-duty recruits in 1987 came from areas in the bottom half of the income distribution for black families, compared with almost 55 percent of white recruits,'' the report said. ``This recruitment pattern of African Americans represented a marked change from 1980, when black recruits were drawn much more heavily from lower income levels,'' the council said in a report on minorities in higher education.

DOC.HEAD: Masked Nationalists Blow Up Cabins At Nudist Colony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE number of cabins destroyed to 60, correct that nudists weren't only ones held; Picks up 5th graf, `Police speculated ...'
DOC.TEXT: Masked gunmen advocating independence for Corsica rounded up nudists and other residents of a holiday complex Sunday and blew up about 60 vacation cabins, police said. There were no injuries or arrests. The letters FNLC, for the Corsican National Liberation Front, were scratched into the hood of a car parked at entrance of the complex. About 60 masked men entered the Corsicana Foret and Corsicana Village camps on the eastern side of the Mediterranean island about 8 a.m., police said. The Corsicana Village camp caters to nudists. They removed about 50 people from the cabins and beaches, bound their hands and held them at a restaurant closed for the winter. Bombers placed explosives in about 60 of the complex's 108 cabins and blew them up four hours later. Police speculated that 50 bottles of gas stolen from a distributor last week were used in the blast, and they cordoned off the area to search for clues. The bombing marks the fourth attack claimed by the nationalist movement since November. The FNLC's aims are to win independence for Corsica and prevent the island from being ``colonized'' by tourists and other outsiders. Tourism and fishing are the main industries on the poor, rugged island of 250,000 people, most of whom are immigrants from mainland France 100 miles away. The native islanders have their own language and customs and have long resisted cultural domination by France.

DOC.HEAD: White Police Kill Black Constable, Newspapers Report
DOC.TEXT: Three white policemen severely beat a black colleague, then left him bleeding outside the station gates, and he later died at a hospital, newspapers reported Sunday. Police have said the Dec. 29 death of Constable Mthakazeli Sangweni has been investigated and the attorney-general would decide whether to bring murder charges. The three officers had not been suspended and police had not reported the case. Police spokesmen said, in response to the newspaper reports, that Sangweni pointed his firearm at an officer when three superiors were speaking to him about an unspecified ``disciplinary matter.'' Police said the constable ``was tackled and overpowered. He later died in hospital, apparently from a head injury sustained in the incident.'' Police refused to comment on reports from the Lawyers for Human Rights group that Sangweni was dumped, bleeding from the nose and mouth, outside the police station, where he lay until fellow black officers called an ambulance to take him to the hospital where he died. Newspapers said the case came to light when black policemen approached the lawyers' group, which has demanded the suspension of the white officers. One newspaper, City Press, said one of the officers is the commander of the police station. The newspapers gave differing accounts, but said the argument involved whether Sangweni had properly performed his job of keeping the police station gate locked. The Sunday Star, quoting Brian Currin of Lawyers for Human Rights, said black officers on the scene reported that Sangweni refused to turn over his firearm to the three white officers, but denied he had aimed it at any of them.

DOC.HEAD: Border Policemen Suspended in Death of Palestinian
DOC.TEXT: Two border policemen were suspended Sunday and ordered to stand trial for fatally shooting a Palestinian teen-ager without first firing warning shots and then allegedly lying about the incident. They were accused of giving a false account after military officers viewed ABC-TV videotape of the shooting, said an army spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity. Also Sunday, a Palestinian man died of gunshot wounds suffered in a clash between masked Arabs and Israeli soldiers three weeks ago in the Gaza Strip, the army said. The victim was identified as Abdulla al-Rekhawi, 42, of the Rafah refugee camp. Two other Palestinians were killed in the clash. After al-Rekhawi's funeral, Palestinians blocked roads with stone barricades and burned tires, Arab reports said. His death raised to 647 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the 25-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. At least 170 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and 43 Israelis have died. The border policemen, members of a paramilitary unit that works with army troops in the territories, were suspended by Maj. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, head of the army's Central Command, and Inspector Gen. Meshulam Amit, the border police commander. The victim, 18-year-old Fadi Zabakli of Bethlehem, was shot in the head during a demonstration Dec. 28 and died Jan. 7. The army initially said Zabakli and fellow Palestinians carried axes and ignored warning shots and orders to halt. Troops are required to shout a warning and fire in the air before aiming at a suspect's legs. Mordechai ordered a probe after ABC-TV reported that the youths were not armed and that no warning shots were fired. The videotape was aired Saturday on Israel television. The names of the two men charged were not made public. Meanwhile, a military court demoted Israeli Lt. David Lior to the rank of sergeant and sentenced him to 45 days in jail for mistreating a Palestinian prisoner, army radio said. According to the radio, Lior kicked and beat a Palestinian after the suspect cursed him in a jeep en route to the lockup. The Palestinian was apprehended for throwing stones. Also Sunday, Italy's ambassador to Israel, Alberto Bartoli, filed a protest on behalf of the European Community with the Israeli Foreign Ministry over police handling of peace rallies in Jerusalem last month. More than 50 people were injured Dec. 30 when police charged a section of the crowd that had gathered to form a ``human chain'' for peace around Jerusalem's Old City. Many were Italian and other European activists. Police said stones and bottles were thrown, but reporters saw no stone throwing before the police moved in. A day earlier, police fired tear gas and used night sticks to break up a women's peace march after an outlawed Palestinian flag was raised. Bartoli's statement criticized ``unjustified use of generalized violence against hundreds of people during authorized, peaceful demonstrations.'' The statement also criticized Israel's decision last week to ban foreign travel by nine Palestinian activists. It said the action was ``not conducive to the climate of confidence necessary for any (peace) negotiation.''

DOC.HEAD: Final Verdicts Near in Nation's Longest, Costliest Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pre-School with hyphen is cq for name of school.
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-three months after the first jurors were summoned to weigh the McMartin Pre-School case, verdicts are nearly complete in the longest, costliest criminal trial ever held in the United States. The molestation trial of Raymond Buckey and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, has become a crucible for the justice system and a soul-wrenching ordeal for participants. Buckey, 31, and his 63-year-old mother await the jury's word _ which could come this week _ on whether they will be found guilty or innocent of 65 counts of child molestation and conspiracy. Parents and their youngsters who once attended the McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach also wait anxiously for the outcome. When the 12 jurors retired for the weekend after eight weeks of deliberation, they had delivered 52 sealed verdicts to Superior Court Judge William Pounders and sent him a question that suggested their verdicts may be as complex as the entire McMartin case. Considering the single count of conspiracy, which names both Buckey and his mother, the jury asked: ``Can we find one defendant guilty and one not guilty?'' Pounders is expected to tell the jury that the answer is yes. They can convict one alleged conspirator without the other because there are a number of unnamed co-conspirators alleged in the charges. The jurors, who have the day off Monday for Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, were to resume deliberations Tuesday. Thirteen verdicts remain to be delivered. Pounders, anxious to learn the results and have the verdicts recorded while 12 jurors remain seated, considered opening the sealed envelopes and disclosing them to the public. But lawyers on both sides persuaded him to wait until the jury's task is concluded. Jurors themselves have expressed fears that disclosure of partial verdicts would subject them to community pressure if any of their decisions proved unpopular. ``I don't mean to betray them,'' said the judge. ``They've done such a great job. But I'm concerned with having 12 jurors here at the end.'' The trial's length forced the judge to use all six alternates to maintain 12 jurors on the panel. There are no alternates left if a juror should fall ill, and a mistrial would have to be called. The 52 verdicts already reached are not official until they are announced in court and affirmed by each juror. ``We have 78 percent of the verdicts in,'' Pounders said. But if I lose one juror I lose all 52 verdicts, which is why I'm on the razor's edge.'' Those familiar with the case don't believe the verdicts will end the bizarre saga that has spread itself over nearly seven years, leaving wrecked lives in its wake. Seven people were originally arrested in 1984, but after a two-year preliminary hearing, charges against the other five were dropped. Appeals could follow any convictions. At least one book is planned on the case no matter what the outcome. ``This case, in my view, has poisoned everyone who had contact with it,'' Pounders said some months ago. Two witnesses had died. Some of the children involved in the proceedings are now adolescents. More than 1,000 items have been entered in evidence and 124 witnesses have testified during the nearly three-year trial. The cost has soared past $15 million. Deputy District Attorney Lael Rubin has said she believes the cost is worthwhile because it has alerted the public to the problem of child molestation. Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, called the McMartin trial ``a cottage industry'' that provided a showcase for experts to build reputations, for lawyers to build careers and for TV news shows to outrate one another. ``My heartfelt feeling is that the truth never had a chance,'' Davis said. ``We rushed into the glitz of a fantastic media event.''

DOC.HEAD: Major Opposition Force Favors Talks on German Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edzard for first name of Daimler-Benz chief is correct.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's largest opposition political party said Sunday that it will open talks on unification with West Germany if it wins national elections in May. Tens of thousands of East Germans demonstrated Sunday against the Communists in at least four cities to keep up the pressure on Communist Premier Hans Modrow's shaky coalition government. ``Forty years of Communist Rule are Enough'' and ``Lies, Corruption and Treason Marked the Communist State,'' read two of the banners at a rally in East Berlin. Several people waved West German flags. Protesters also rallied in Magdeburg, Karl-Marx-Stadt and Suhl, according to East German television. The leading opposition party, Social Democrats, originally organized the East Berlin demonstration to pay tribute to two German Communists murdered 71 years ago. The two, Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht, have become martyrs for German leftists. Several hundred thousand people across East Germany took part in various ceremonies marking their deaths Jan. 15, 1919. For the first time, the events were not controlled by the Communist Party. In a party platform statement released after a meeting, the Social Democrats said Sunday that if they lead the government after elections on May 6, they will open talks with Bonn on ``the necessary steps'' for German unity. The statement said: ``Our political goal is a united Germany.'' ``Whatever is possible immediately, should happen immediately,'' the Social Democrats said. The 500 delegates said German unity must come as part of an overall process of European integration, and it must have the consent of neighboring countries. On Saturday, the West German Social Democrats promised campaign support for their sister party in East Germany, which has 32,000 members and has emerged as a top contender to win East Germany's first open elections. The far larger New Forum opposition group, with an estimated 200,000 members, remains a diffuse organization with little interest in becoming a formal political party. The Communist Party still has 1.4 million members, despite a wave of resignations, and has a grip on businesses, bureaucracy and the news media. Even before Sunday's announcement by the Social Democrats, the two German states were well on their way toward unification. Political, cultural and business ties are growing daily, in a spirit of cooperation unthinkable before the ouster of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker on Oct. 18, the opening of the Berlin Wall in November, and a series of democratic reforms. Daimler-Benz chief Edzard Reuter, whose conglomerate makes trucks, Mercedes-Benz cars, aerospace products and electronics equipment, said he will start working with East German leaders even before the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Blames Regulators for S&L Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings and Loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. said Sunday that taxpayers could have been saved half a trillion dollars in savings and loan losses if regulators had listened to the five senators for whom he raised campaign money. Keating, who is a central figure in the S&L crisis and an accompanying congressional ethics scandal involving the five senators, blamed regulators for the collapse of Lincoln and hundreds of other thrifts. ``Had they listened to the senators and had they listened to me, there wouldn't be mess today,'' he said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' show. ``I'm convinced that the cost of this debacle is going to exceed $500 billion. ... Never ... has so much misery and economic disaster been caused by so few men.'' Keating defended raising $1.3 million from associates for political campaigns and related causes of Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John McCain, R-Ariz.; Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. Edwin Gray, a former chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, and federal S&L examiners told a House committee last fall they were pressured by the senators in a pair of meetings in DeConcini's office in 1987 to ease their regulation of Lincoln. ``I wanted to be involved in the process,'' Keating said Sunday. ``It was particularly important how the savings and loan industry went. It you want to support the system, you have to, in my case, it seems to me, raise funds and support the people.'' Since the disclosures of the campaign gifts and the meeting with regulators, the five senators have tried to disassociate themselves from Keating, saying they didn't know at the time the nature of Lincoln's loans and investments. All five are now the subject of a Senate Ethics Committee inquiry. Asked Sunday if the meetings between the senators and bank board officials over Lincoln was unusual, Keating said his problem with the regulators were more than ordinary. ``It was a problem of taking down a savings and loan which was critical to the economy and employment in those areas in which the senators served,'' he said. Claiming that the Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln was being operated in an ``unsafe and unsound manner,'' the bank board seized control of it last April, two years after examiners first recommended shutting it down. Regulators now estimate that its loss of federally insured taxes through what the government claims in a suit were fraudulent loans and racketeering investment practices will cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. Keating, in turn, has sued the government, claiming its takeover of Lincoln was part of a vendetta that regulators waged against him because he was operating Lincoln as an investment bank rather than as a traditional home mortgage lender. ``It operated profitably until the government confiscated it,'' he said Sunday. ``It seems to me that something's wrong for the government that takes away a profitable property. There's no loss that's ascertainable at this point in Lincoln.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Minister Arrives With Hussein Message After River Cutback
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's oil minister arrived Sunday for talks on Turkey's reduction of the Euphrates River flow toward Iraq and Syria. The newspaper of Iraq's ruling Baath Socialist Party said relations between Turkey and its neighbors could suffer if Turkey does not let the water flow freely again. The Iraqi minister, Issam Abdul Rahim Al-Chalabi, arried with him a message from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for Turkey's president, Turgut Ozal. He refused to tell reporters what the letter said. On Saturday, Ozal cut the flow of the Euphrates with the push of a button, diverting its waters to a reservoir that is part of a huge dam and hydroelectric project in southeastern Turkey. During the one-month stoppage, Syria and Iraq will get 75 percent less water from the tributaries of the Euphrates. Iraq sent its deputy foreign minister, Nizar Hamdoun, to Turkey last month to try to get the reduction in flow shortened from one month to two weeks. Turkey refused, saying a month was necessary to fill the reservoir. Turks maintain that since November they have released extra water to Syria and Iraq to store in reservoirs in preparation for the shortfall.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman's Widow Has Twins In Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: The widow of Texas Congressman Mickey Leland, who was expecting at the time of his death in a plane crash last summer, gave birth Sunday to twin boys at an Atlanta hospital, a spokesman said. Alison Leland, 31, was in town for festivities surrounding Monday's Martin Luther King Jr. national holiday. Mrs. Leland came to Grady Memorial Hospital about 5 a.m. Sunday, and gave birth to the boys around noon, according to Grady spokesman Jim Driscoll. She and the boys _ one 3 pounds, the other 2 pounds, 11 ounces _ are doing well, Driscoll said. But the infants, several weeks premature, are in Grady's special care nursery. Mrs. Leland was about six weeks pregnant when Leland, 44, was killed Aug. 7 in a plane crash in Ethiopia while on a hunger relief mission. He was first elected to Congress from Houston's 18th District in 1978. On Leland's behalf, his widow accepted a ``Salute to Greatness'' award from the King Center on Saturday night. In late August, Mrs. Leland declined to run for his seat in Congress, saying her top priorities were her son _ Jarrett, now 4 _ and the ``new baby on the way.''

DOC.HEAD: As The Khmer Rouge Advance, Nations Speed Up Efforts to Settle Conflict
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The search for a negotiated settlement of the Cambodian war has quickened amid reports of Khmer Rouge guerrilla advances from the jungles. Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Rogachev of the Soviet Union on Friday announced after talks in Beijing that the Soviet Union and China have agreed the United Nations should play ``a very major role'' in a Cambodian settlement. The Soviet Union has been arming the Vietnamese-installed Cambodian government, and China arms the guerrillas. The Soviet announcement increased hopes that are centered on Australia's proposal for a U.N. interim authority in Cambodia, which diplomats call the most promising peace plan in years. The Soviet Union, China and the three other permanent members of the U.N. Security Council will discuss that and other Cambodian peace initiatives at a meeting in Paris on Monday and Tuesday. The plan would require approval by the members, which also include the United States, Britain, and France. Fears of a Khmer Rouge return have intensified since September, when Vietnam said it withdrew the last of its troops aiding the Hanoi-installed government. The Khmer Rouge claimed last week that its forces hit the two largest cities, Phnom Penh and Battambang. Phnom Penh sources said minor explosons went off in the capital on Jan. 5 and 6. The government said the guerrillas also struck near Battambang, the provincial capital in the northwest. The guerrillas said they set parts of the city ablaze, but the reports could not be verified. Western diplomats said the effect of the attacks was ``more psychological than strategic'' and involved little actual fighting. They predicted more strikes in coming weeks, designed not to overthrow the government but to bolster bargaining power at peace talks. After toppling the U.S.-backed Lon Nol government in April 1975, the Khmer Rouge emptied the cities and banished residents to labor camps in the countryside. Hundreds of thousands were executed, died of torture or disease in labor camps during the 3{-year rule of Pol Pot's black-clad fanatics. Vietnam's invasion of December 1978 drove the Khmer Rouge to the Thai border. But aid from Thailand and China revived the guerrillas and they formed a coalition that includes the non-Comunist forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann. ``If we let the situation persist and the Khmer Rouge gain more ground, they might harden their stance at the negotiating table,'' said Ek Sereywath, a spokesman in Sihanouk's office in Bangkok. The Australian proposal says a U.N. authority should govern Cambodia until a free election can be held. Foreign Minister Ali Alatas of Indonesia on Thursday praised the proposal because among the many issues unsettled at the international conference on Cambodia last summer, ``one of the most difficult to overcome was the question of an interim administering authority.'' In that conference, Premier Hun Sen of Cambodia rejected guerrilla demands for a transitional coalition government because of the inclusion of the Khmer Rouge. Other unresolved issues, Alatas said, include verification of Vietnam's claimed troop pullout, a truce and a halt to outside military aid to the combatants, and measures to prevent a return of the Khmer Rouge terror. Deputy Foreign Secretary Michael Costello of Australia will try to gather support for the plan in visits to France, the United Nations and the United States. The main antagonists at any talks will be Hun Sen and Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan. Their will to fight has not weakened. In a speech Jan. 6, Hun Sen urged authorities to step up recruitment ``at all costs. We must strengthen the armed forces. Without the armed forces we cannot survive.'' The Khmer Rouge radio said the government surely will fall and told citizens to flee immediately ``in order to live.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
